title: Shorten renews call to lift NDIS staff cap
text:
Bill Shorten has renewed calls to scrap a cap on the number of workers administering the National Disability Insurance Scheme.

The former Labor leader went to the federal election in May promising to abolish staffing limits at the responsible agency, and lost.

"You don't need an election to fix the NDIS," Mr Shorten told a breakfast function in Canberra on Wednesday.

He asked NDIS Minister Stuart Robert, who spoke before Mr Shorten, to lift the cap in an act of bipartisanship.

He pointed to the over 1000 NDIS related matters currently before the Australian Administrative Tribunal.

He also said people on the scheme were only spending about 69 per cent of their funding packages.

"And that is not because the demand isn't there for 100 per cent of the package," Mr Shorten said.

"You can't say it is a demand-driven program and have a fixed cap on staff, it is a contradiction.

"You can't be voting in the parliament this week on streamlining corporate governance of the NDIA and the NDIS and not provide extra staff."

Mr Shorten's comments were met with applause by the audience.

He said carers who were conversant in "NDIS language" were easily able to navigate the system, while others languished.

Mr Shorten said he met in Launceston a woman with a degenerative brain disease who had spent months waiting for the agency to approve a hoist for her to use at home.

"She said to me she's essentially going to become a head as (the disease) eats every part of her body," he said.
